text: alright so I'm Karissa I'm a partner at
paradigm my background is in psychology
so that's where I'm coming out this work
from I got my PhD in 2013 from Stanford
where i worked with Professor carol
dweck and studied growth versus fixed
mindsets what I'm generally really
passionate about is conducting research
and applied settings or applying the
lessons of research so before I came to
paradigm while I was a grad student at
Stanford i co-founded an organization
called PERTs to apply research on
mindsets in education and now I'm really
excited to be working on the paradigm
team applying research both my own and a
lot of the research that you all are
doing in fact to increase the
representation of women and people
people of color in workplaces and to
create environments where everyone can
be successful one problem one barrier
that I see to that is what I'll be
calling the culture of brilliance or a
fixed mindset culture in the tech
industry so just to give a bit of
background on fixed versus growth
mindset there's been a lot of research
showing that people tend to think about
the nature of talents and abilities in
really different ways so some people
have more of a fixed mindset they tend
to believe that abilities and talents
are fixed at birth so they think of them
kind of like eye color you either have
blue eyes or you don't you were born
with certain talents and abilities and
not others and there's not really much
you can do to change that other people
have more of a growth mindset they
believe that abilities and talents can
be developed so they think of them more
like a muscle so just like when you work
out at the gym you can make your muscles
stronger when you work hard to develop
your talents and abilities you can make
your brain stronger at the individual
level there are a lot of important
consequences for these mindsets so these
mindsets influence the goals that people
have people with a fixed mindset are
more interested in proving themselves
while people with the growth mindset are
more interested in improving they also
influence how we think about effort in a
fixed mindset effort feels really bad if
I have to try I must not be very smart
and it influences how people respond to
challenges people with a fixed mindset
tend to give up in the face of
challenges they think they've discovered
something they're not good at people
with the growth mindset really embrace
and I
like challenges because that's when
they're learning the most more recent
research shows that like individuals
organizations and even entire fields can
have mindsets and these mindsets also
have really important consequences there
so for example recent research shows
that field whose practitioners believe
that brilliance is required for success
have fewer women who are earning phd's
in those fields at the organization
level companies who portray a fixed
mindset culture for example by saying on
their website that they're interested in
hiring employees who have the abilities
and talents we're looking for women are
less likely to want to apply to those
compy companies then when companies
portraying were of a growth mindset
culture by saying that they want to help
employees learn discover and grow so why
is this happening it's of course not
because women aren't brilliant what's
going on is that we have stereotypes
about who is brilliant in our society
and those stereotypes call to mind
images of white men so in fact in this
same study they found that the reason
why women were less likely to want to
apply to the fixed mindset company is
because they believed they'd be more
likely to be stereotyped in those
companies they thought that management
at the fixed mindset company would be
less likely to view them as smart
qualified assertive and well-spoken so
just want to leave you with a couple of
ideas about what we can actually do to
foster more of a growth mindset
culturing organizations so just two
strategies one is how do companies
respond to mistakes and failures
especially for companies who really care
about innovating it's really important
that people feel comfortable kind of
making mistakes but in a fixed mindset
culture mistakes mean you're stupid
you're going to be less likely to take
take on those challenges and it can be
especially threatening to do that if
you're a member of a stereotyped group
one way to kind of fight against this to
foster more of a growth mindset culture
is to reward people for taking risks
even when those risks don't meet don't
necessarily lead to the intended outcome
so for example Google has a really
interesting award called the fab you
this flat board to encourage people to
take risk and then kind of reward them
even if those don't work out another
opportunity that companies have to
foster more of a growth mindset is in
when they give feedback so feedback that
focuses on the process of how work gets
done versus the person innate traits
foster is more of a growth mindset
culture so for example instead of saying
something like you're a really good
communicator say why so I really like
that you communicate clearly with your
colleagues and you have a positive
attitude that that helps foster growth
mindset by helping people understand
that their success is tied to their
effort and strategies rather than the
innate ability it's also just more
useful feedback research in my own
research in a study led by Liz Gunderson
we found that parents who gave their
kids process praise had kids with more
of a growth mindset five years later so
when we when we change our language that
can really shape what people believe is
important for success and that can
influence how people think about and
approach their work thank you
